In algebraic terms, a circle is the set of points (x, y) at some fixed distance (r) from some fixed point (h, k). The value of r is called the "radius" of the circle, and the point (h, k) is called the "center" of the circle. Circle may also be considered a special kind of ellipse.
 Twice the radius = Diameter
 Perimeter =  Circumference.

This means that if diameter is 1 then circumference is 3.14, which is pi (π).
That is why circumference is 2rπ, since diameter = 2r.
